title: Chevrolet's New Volt Has Battery With 53-Mile Range
text:
Reprint 
NEW YORK ( TheStreet ) -- Chevrolet said on Tuesday that its next-generation electric hybrid, the 2016 Volt , can reach a 53-mile range using only its lithium-ion battery power, according to official figures from the Environmental Protection Agency. 
When the gasoline-powered engine kicks in, the car can then travel up to 420 miles in total. The almost 40% increase in battery life from the original model means that most car journeys won't require any gas at all. Chevrolet estimates that around 90% of car trips will be completed using only the battery charge, alleviating much of consumers' "range anxiety," or fear about the range of a battery. 
General Motors ( GM - Get Report ) announced that Chevrolet's 2016 Volt will hit the market this fall with a price tag of $33,995 and that drivers will be entitled to a federal tax credit. Outside California, the price could drop to $26,495 when government incentives are applied. 
The outgoing Volt model could travel only 38 miles on the electric charge, and its successor is also over $1,000 cheaper, as Chevrolet works to convert customers to the electric-hybrid models.

Chevrolet claims that the 2016 Volt will save customers about $5,500 in fuel costs over a five-year period. The car takes 4.5 hours to recharge, and fuel efficiency has also been improved when the engine kicks in after the first 53 miles.
